author: Anderson
title: An Experimental Investigation of the Impact of Video Media on Pork Consumption
brief_description: an evaluation of Animal Equality’s iAnimal campaign, "a virtual reality project that creates a 360-degree, immersive experience to give viewers a look into the day-to-day life of animals raised for food in factory farms and slaughterhouses"
outcome: whether participants abstain from eating pork or not

author: Anderson
title: An Experimental Investigation of the Impact of Video Media on Pork Consumption
brief_description: an evaluation of Animal Equality’s  traditional 2D video outreach
outcome: whether participants abstain from eating pork or not

author: Carfora (a)
title: Correlational study and randomised controlled trial for understanding and changing red meat consumption: The role of eating identities
brief_description: daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of red meat consumption
outcome: red meat consumption  (RMC)

author: Carfora (a)
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on health and the environment.
outcome: self-reported Red and Processed Meat Consumption

author: Carfora (a)
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on the environment
outcome: self-reported Red and Processed Meat Consumption

author: Carfora (a)
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on health
outcome: self-reported Red and Processed Meat Consumption

author: Carfora (b)
title: Randomised controlled trial of a text messaging intervention for reducing processed meat consumption: The mediating roles of anticipated regret and intention
brief_description: first an email about the recommended dosage of procssed meat consumption and then daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of processed meat consumption
outcome: processed meat consumption (PMC)

author: Carfora (b)
title: Informational and emotional daily messages to reduce red and processed meat consumption
brief_description: two weeks of messages "informing them about the health and environmental impact of excessive RPMC (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red and processed meat, you will not protect your health from colon cancer, and at the same time you will not protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”)" along with an emotional component asking them to think about their anticipated regret
outcome: food frequency questionnaire (servings of red and processed meat per week)

author: Carfora (b)
title: Informational and emotional daily messages to reduce red and processed meat consumption
brief_description: two weeks of messages "informing them about the health and environmental impact of excessive RPMC (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red and processed meat, you will not protect your health from colon cancer, and at the same time you will not protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”)"
outcome: food frequency questionnaire (servings of red and processed meat per week)

author: Delichatsios
title: Randomized Trial of a “Talking Computer” to Improve Adults' Eating Habits
brief_description: "Weekly communicationfor 6 months via a totally automated, computer-based voice system. Amongintervention group subjects, the system monitored dietary habitsand provided educational feedback, advice, and behavioral counseling. Control group subjects received physical activity promotioncounseling."
outcome: red and processed meat via PrimeScreen Instrument

author: Dijkstra
title: Lowering Red Meat and Processed Meat Consumption With Environmental, Animal Welfare, and Health Arguments in Italy: An Online Experiment
brief_description: text with pictures on the environmental, animal welfare, or health consequences of meat consumption
outcome: self-reported red meat consumption

author: Emmons (a)
title: Project PREVENT: A Randomized Trial to Reduce Multiple Behavioral Risk Factors for Colon Cancer
brief_description: education targeting behavioral risk factors for colorectal cancer among individuals who have been diagnosed with adenomatous colon polyps
outcome: red meat consumption (RMC)

author: Emmons (b)
title: Cancer Prevention Among Working Class, Multiethnic Adults: Results of the Healthy Directions–Health Centers Study
brief_description: social-contextual approach ta geting multiple levels of influence on behaviors, with special attention to low literacy skills and the shared and unique features of culture across racial/ethnic groups
outcome: red meat consumption (RMC) -- 3 or fewer servings per week

author: Jaacks
title: Long-term changes in dietary and food intake behaviour in the Diabetes Prevention Program Outcomes Study
brief_description: "16-session core curriculum over the first 24 weeks, followed by an individualized counselling curriculum (at least monthly contact) with the primary intervention goals of achieving and maintaining a weight loss of ≥ 7% initial body weight and a moderate intensity activity level of ≥ 150 min per week [20]. Participants were advised to reduce dietary fat gram intake to < 25% of total calories based on a calorie estimate to achieve the weight loss goal, with the addition of a calorie goal if weight loss was not achieved after the first seven sessions"
outcome: red meat servings per day

author: James
title: Impact of a nutrition and physical activity intervention (ENRICH: Exercise and Nutrition Routine Improving Cancer Health) on health behaviors of cancer survivors and carers: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
intervention_condition: ENRICH: Exercise and Nutrition Routine Improving Cancer Health
brief_description: Four weekly, 2-h sessions, and two 2-h fortnightly sessions were provided (total 6 sessions) with a mix of didactic information about health and physical activity as well as some "practical activities (e.g., label reading, recipe modification, demonstration and practice of resist- ance exercises, setting step goals for the home-based walk- ing program)."
outcome: red meat (grams per day)

author: Lee
title: Dietary and physical activity interventions for colorectal cancer survivors: a randomized controlled trial
brief_description: "Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) and the Health Action Process Approach (HAPA)" intervention with face to face conversations, phone calls, "educational pamphlets, mailed quarterly newsletters, and quarterly group meetings"
outcome: percent of people meeting the food targets for red meat reduction

author: Lindström
title: Nudging towards sustainable meat consumption: a natural field experiment
brief_description: two nudges and an appeal: colorful footsteps leading to the sustainable option, placing healthy options side by side with minced beef, and a message saying that carrots and beans are good for health, the environment, and animals
outcome: kilograms of minced beef sold per week

author: Perino
title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: a quote from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (interspecies benefits).
outcome: binary variable for whether their surveyed meal contained red meat or not

author: Perino
title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: a quote from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (environmental benefits).
outcome: binary variable for whether their surveyed meal contained red meat or not

author: Perino
title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: a quote from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (personal health).
outcome: binary variable for whether their surveyed meal contained red meat or not

author: Schatzkin
title: Lack of Effect of a Low-Fat, High-Fiber Diet on the Recurrence of Colorectal Adenoma
brief_description: Low-Fat, High-Fiber Diet for adults with histologically confirmed colorectal adenomas delivered via "more than 50 hours of" intensive counseling involving "nutritional information and behavior-modification techniques" delivered over four years, "including 20 hours in the first year"
outcome: red and processed meat (grams per day)

author: Sorensen
title: Promoting Behavior Change Among Working-Class, Multiethnic Workers: Results of the Healthy Directions–Small Business Study
intervention_condition: cancer prevention intervention designed to prompote healthy behaviors
brief_description: "integrated interventions focused on nutrition, physical activity, and occupational health and activities focused on individual risk factors"
outcome: </= 3 servings of red meat per week

author: Wolstenholme
title: Two Birds, One Stone: The Effectiveness of Health and Environmental Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption and Encourage Pro-environmental Behavioral Spillover
brief_description: daily message via automated private chat on Facebook Messenger about health reasons to eat less RPM
outcome: 15-point response scale from 0 to 14 servings or more of red and processed meat (separately)

author: Wolstenholme
title: Two Birds, One Stone: The Effectiveness of Health and Environmental Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption and Encourage Pro-environmental Behavioral Spillover
brief_description: daily message via automated private chat on Facebook Messenger about environmental reasons to eat less RPM, e.g. "If you eat only a small amount of red and processed meat, you will protect the environment by reducing excessive land use. Remember to try and eat no more than two portions of red and processed meat this week. Please record all of the food you have eaten today using today’s food diary."
outcome: 15-point response scale from 0 to 14 servings or more of red and processed meat (separately)

author: Wolstenholme
title: Two Birds, One Stone: The Effectiveness of Health and Environmental Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption and Encourage Pro-environmental Behavioral Spillover
brief_description: daily message via automated private chat on Facebook Messenger about health environmental reasons to eat less RPM
outcome: 15-point response scale from 0 to 14 servings or more of red and processed meat (separately)
